Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature (T) at any spatial point (x,y) in a region follows the heat equation given by \\(\\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\nabla^2 T\\), where \\(\\alpha\\) is the thermal diffusivity. We study the effects of applying a Fourier transform on the temperature distribution, denoted as \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)\\), and analyze its influence over time.

Can we determine exactly which transformations were applied (whether \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)\\), \\(\\mathcal{G}(T)\\), or both) just by observing the final state \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)(T)\\)?
Explanation: The final transformed state \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)(T)\\) may result from several combinations of interventions and initial conditions. Distinguishing whether the initial state was transformed by \\(\\mathcal{F}(T)\\), only to be later modified by \\(\\mathcal{G}(T)\\), or some other sequence, is ambiguous without additional information due to overlapping effects in the transformed domain.
